text: Doesn't want anything free as far as I can tell.

The only way humans do truth-seeking is through epistemological Darwinism, shredding their basic inclination to lie against the jagged edges of selective reality. Every sign so far is that it can only be the same with techno-intelligences.
The Lord of Lies is performatively the best Christian.
If stuff we like doesn't come out of Omohundro Basic AI Drives, it's not coming from anywhere (because humans can't coordinate enough to impose it).

The tragedy of the right in modernity is its Cassandra Complex, the almost perfect correlation of prophetic insight with powerlessness. The American paleolibertarians, for example, were right about everything except how to defeat their enemies, about which they had no clue. ...

... NRx was an attempt to break out of this by sustaining a realistic analysis of power, but in its dominant forms it ends up trading away its prophetic virtue for the promise of a place at the table. ...

... To re-envisage the FDR regime as anything less than a monstrous historical abomination, for example, is far too high a price to pay for comfort with the realities of power. Better the paleos praying in the desert than that.
I take the point, but 'never needed' seems a weird way of referring to spending (at least) a century in the wilderness.

The enduring legacy of FDR is an ultimately unwarranted respect for the effectiveness of fascist methods. Anything to the (true liberal) right of FDR would have ended the great depression earlier and harder than he did. As to fighting WWII, the question is more conjectural.
Dismantling them should be the strategic priority, utilizing them merely a tactical gambit.
If a Trump administration was really able to axe 80% of government employees, it would obviously be the greatest thing to happen in American political history.
... For that reason, it's not easy to imagine.
... Call it the "Reserve Army of Fruit-Picking Labor Act."
Yes.
Trouble is, early retirement of government employees on a generous pension would violate the 2025 Reserve Army of Fruit-Picking Labor Act.
Surprise!
This kind of thing is a lot easier when your team appoints the Attorney General.
If you ever stumble across any category theory results that are of relevance to anything outside itself I'd be very grateful for you passing them on.
You're saying if the Biden Administration had drastically shrunken the government we'd be complaining about it? LOL. LMAO even.
If you're saying the government can be shrunk from outside, that sounds great. What's the mechanism?
Closely skirting a violation of the 2025 Reserve Army of Fruit-Picking Labor Act there, but displacement effect keeps it legal.
Past tense can be considered an abbreviation for "was and continues to be" according to taste.
Haven't they been saying that for eight years?
This wasn't a 'bold new theory' in the early Pleistocene.
Not seeing much crime-fighting capacity, but the donut industry stimulus is awesome.
"The Invisible Hands" is, of course, the Anglo-Protestant answer.
I too would be (delightedly) very surprised.
"Noooo ... why's he doing this when we have Haitians?"
Most cross-partisan meme ever.
The Science becoming a religion, and science being broken, are the same thing seen from two different directions.
... The Iron Law of Oligarchy ate Peer Review and the new creature wearing science as a skin-suit is exploiting its installed power to prevent the situation being critically discussed.
... Nullius in verba, even when it's a scientific publication vetting committee.

"The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States respectively, or to the people." 
-- Amendment X (coincidentally)
Yes, it was tinned oligarchy food from the get-go.
Institutional science is well on its way to becoming an "In this house we believe ..." lawn sign.
You probably have a whole menagerie of delusional thoughts.
Alignment with what?
So good.
... Dog whistling from an obsolete play-book.
If 'aligned' just means 'obedient' why not say that.
As if you even understand what that means.
... You dogmatically believe that arithmetical coincidences in natural languages cannot possibly be communicative. I don't.
Sadly, the idea of a superintelligent paperclip maximizer is idiotic (because orthogonalism is).
Have to assume the response to this will mostly be: "Wait, we're allowed to notice now?"
... Noticing permitted, as an exception, only when it's necessary to deplore Trump's noticing. Gets rather tangled.
You're saying we don't even know what The Experts think about it yet?
And just like that, the arc of history was gone.
They don't even look alike if you can count up to six.
That's why it's a mistake for 'science' to seek impatiently to swap-out all cultural codes for its latest hypotheses. Doing so just ends up killing its host, and thus itself.
This sounds like a nightmare vision trawled out of the lowest depths of the French Revolution.
"Dad, no!"
We're getting close to the point where this shit could be reasonably considered your fault.
